trans-unit.source: Scheduler REST API Reference
trans-unit.target: Scheduler REST API Reference

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to perform common tasks in Azure Scheduler by using the Scheduler management REST API.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to perform common tasks in Azure Scheduler by using the Scheduler management REST API.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: A valid <token>azure_2</token> account and an active <token>azure_2</token> subscription are required.
trans-unit.target: A valid <token>azure_2</token> account and an active <token>azure_2</token> subscription are required.

trans-unit.source: This documentation assumes that you already have an active subscription and associated subscription ID.
trans-unit.target: This documentation assumes that you already have an active subscription and associated subscription ID.

trans-unit.source: A management certificate for your <token>azure_2</token> subscription.
trans-unit.target: A management certificate for your <token>azure_2</token> subscription.

trans-unit.source: A management certificate is required to authenticate client access to resources in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: A management certificate is required to authenticate client access to resources in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You must use an X-509 v3 certificate that contains a public key and has a .cer file name extension.
trans-unit.target: You must use an X-509 v3 certificate that contains a public key and has a .cer file name extension.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to create a management certificate, see <externalLink><linkText>Manage Certificates in Azure</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg981929.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For information on how to create a management certificate, see <externalLink><linkText>Manage Certificates in Azure</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/gg981929.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: The Scheduler API provides a RESTful set of operations that interact with Azure Scheduler service to manage your scheduled jobs and job collections.
trans-unit.target: The Scheduler API provides a RESTful set of operations that interact with Azure Scheduler service to manage your scheduled jobs and job collections.

trans-unit.source: The Scheduler management API enables a core set of site administration scenarios:
trans-unit.target: The Scheduler management API enables a core set of site administration scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Create, update, and delete “job collections” programmatically
trans-unit.target: Create, update, and delete “job collections” programmatically

trans-unit.source: Create, update, delete scheduled jobs programmatically
trans-unit.target: Create, update, delete scheduled jobs programmatically

trans-unit.source: View list of job collections and jobs programmatically
trans-unit.target: View list of job collections and jobs programmatically

trans-unit.source: View job status and history programmatically
trans-unit.target: View job status and history programmatically

trans-unit.source: Resources
trans-unit.target: Resources

trans-unit.source: The Azure Scheduler REST API exposes the following hierarchy of resources for managing your jobs and job collections:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Scheduler REST API exposes the following hierarchy of resources for managing your jobs and job collections:

trans-unit.source: Operations on Resources
trans-unit.target: Operations on Resources

trans-unit.source: To determine whether the service has finished processing a request, call <externalLink><linkText>Get Operation Status</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460783.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>, especially if you need to use that resource on a subsequent call or if you need to ensure that a modification or deletion really happened.
trans-unit.target: To determine whether the service has finished processing a request, call <externalLink><linkText>Get Operation Status</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460783.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>, especially if you need to use that resource on a subsequent call or if you need to ensure that a modification or deletion really happened.

trans-unit.source: For more information on asynchronous operations, see <externalLink><linkText>Tracking Asynchronous Service Management Requests</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460791.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on asynchronous operations, see <externalLink><linkText>Tracking Asynchronous Service Management Requests</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460791.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Creating a resource
trans-unit.target: Creating a resource

trans-unit.source: New resources are created with an HTTP POST or PUT verb.
trans-unit.target: New resources are created with an HTTP POST or PUT verb.

trans-unit.source: If the resource is created successfully, an HTTP 200 (OK), 201 (created), or 202 (accepted) status code is returned, and the serialized resource object is included in the response body.
trans-unit.target: If the resource is created successfully, an HTTP 200 (OK), 201 (created), or 202 (accepted) status code is returned, and the serialized resource object is included in the response body.

trans-unit.source: If a client attempts to create a resource that already exists, an HTTP 400 (bad request) or 409 (conflict) status code is returned.
trans-unit.target: If a client attempts to create a resource that already exists, an HTTP 400 (bad request) or 409 (conflict) status code is returned.

trans-unit.source: Reading a resource
trans-unit.target: Reading a resource

trans-unit.source: To read the current state of an existing resource, an HTTP GET verb is used.
trans-unit.target: To read the current state of an existing resource, an HTTP GET verb is used.

trans-unit.source: If the resource exists, then the response status code is 200 or 202 and the response body will contain a serialized object.
trans-unit.target: If the resource exists, then the response status code is 200 or 202 and the response body will contain a serialized object.

trans-unit.source: If the resource does not exist, then response status code is 400 (bad request) or 404 (not found).
trans-unit.target: If the resource does not exist, then response status code is 400 (bad request) or 404 (not found).

trans-unit.source: Updating a resource
trans-unit.target: Updating a resource

trans-unit.source: Existing resources are updated with an HTTP PUT or PATCH verb.
trans-unit.target: Existing resources are updated with an HTTP PUT or PATCH verb.

trans-unit.source: The name of the object is passed in the URL string, and the new state of the object is passed in the request body.
trans-unit.target: The name of the object is passed in the URL string, and the new state of the object is passed in the request body.

trans-unit.source: If the resource is updated successfully, an HTTP 200 or 202 status code is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the resource is updated successfully, an HTTP 200 or 202 status code is returned.

trans-unit.source: If the resource to be updated does not exist, an HTTP 400 (bad request) or 404 (not found) status code is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the resource to be updated does not exist, an HTTP 400 (bad request) or 404 (not found) status code is returned.

trans-unit.source: Deleting a resource
trans-unit.target: Deleting a resource

trans-unit.source: An existing resource is deleted with an HTTP DELETE verb.
trans-unit.target: An existing resource is deleted with an HTTP DELETE verb.

trans-unit.source: The name of the object is passed in the URL string.
trans-unit.target: The name of the object is passed in the URL string.

trans-unit.source: If the resource is deleted successfully, an HTTP 200 or 202 status code is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the resource is deleted successfully, an HTTP 200 or 202 status code is returned.

trans-unit.source: If the object has already been deleted or does not exist, then HTTP 400 or 404 is returned.
trans-unit.target: If the object has already been deleted or does not exist, then HTTP 400 or 404 is returned.

trans-unit.source: Authentication
trans-unit.target: Authentication

trans-unit.source: To call the Azure Scheduler APIs successfully, you will need a management certificate that is associated with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: To call the Azure Scheduler APIs successfully, you will need a management certificate that is associated with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Authenticating Service Management Requests</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460782.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Authenticating Service Management Requests</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/ee460782.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: The Scheduler service endpoint is exposed only through https, to help mitigate information disclosure threats.
trans-unit.target: The Scheduler service endpoint is exposed only through https, to help mitigate information disclosure threats.
